name: Perospirone
summary: Perospirone is an atypical antipsychotic used primarily for the treatment of schizophrenia and, in some cases, bipolar disorder.
description: Perospirone is a serotonin-dopamine antagonist (SDA) with high affinity for 5-HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors, offering antipsychotic effects with a potentially lower risk of extrapyramidal symptoms than typical antipsychotics. It is approved for schizophrenia treatment in Japan and some other countries but is not widely available globally. Its pharmacological profile also includes partial agonist activity at 5-HT1A receptors, which may contribute to its anxiolytic and antidepressant effects.

contraindications: Hypersensitivity to perospirone or related compounds

items: Management of manic episodes in bipolar disorder

sections.text: Perospirone acts as an antagonist at serotonin 5-HT2A and dopamine D2 receptors, reducing psychotic symptoms. Its partial agonism at 5-HT1A receptors may enhance mood and reduce anxiety.

adult.Schizophrenia: Typically 8–48 mg/day in divided doses; start low and titrate.
adult.Bipolar disorder (mania): Similar dosing to schizophrenia; adjust based on response.

sections.geriatric: Lower starting doses recommended; monitor for orthostatic hypotension and sedation.

sections.text: Some symptom relief may occur within 1–2 weeks; full effect may take several weeks.

sections.black_box: Elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis treated with antipsychotics are at increased risk of death.
other: May cause metabolic changes including hyperglycemia and dyslipidemia

sections.pregnancy: Use only if benefits outweigh risks; limited human data.
sections.lactation: Unknown if excreted in breast milk; caution advised.

sections.text: Gradual dose reduction recommended to reduce withdrawal and relapse risk.

items: Pharmacologically similar to other SDAs but with 5-HT1A partial agonist activity
